Network traffic from internal hosts conn.Action: Analyze Zeek conn.log for connections originating from internal hosts to known social media platform domains/IPs. Identify hosts exhibiting unusually high volume or frequency of connections, or connections at unusual times. Use time series analysis to identify deviations from baseline connection patterns.

Host process creation events on internal.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 (Process Creation) on endpoints. Filter for processes associated with social media or web browsing applications. Look for process creation chains or command line arguments potentially indicative of non-standard interaction with these applications. Use frequency analysis to identify unusual application usage patterns across endpoints.

Execution of host processes related to c.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 for processes related to credential access (e.g., `lsass.exe` access patterns, credential manager tools, or suspicious scripting engines like `powershell.exe`, `python.exe`) or suspicious scripting activity. Correlate these events with Zeek conn.log entries showing connections from the same host to social media domains within a short time window (e.g., +/- 5 minutes). Use correlation analysis to identify pairs of events (suspicious process + social media connection) occurring together more frequently than expected for individual hosts or user accounts.

Unusual volume or frequency of data uplo.Action: Analyze Zeek conn.log (examining `orig_bytes` for bytes sent) and Zeek http.log (if available, examining method like POST/PUT and response body size if relevant) for connections from internal hosts to social media domains. Establish a baseline of normal upload volume and frequency per host/user using descriptive statistics (mean, median, IQR, standard deviation). Flag uploads exceeding a statistically significant deviation from the baseline (e.g., > 3 standard deviations or exceeding the 95th percentile) or connections occurring with unusually high frequency in a short period (time series analysis).
